title: The Kickstart Question
summary: Begin conversations with a powerful, open-ended question to surface what matters most.

details.content: Starting with the right question sets the tone for a productive coaching conversation and helps uncover the real issue quickly.
Ask, 'What's on your mind?' at the start of a meeting to invite honest discussion and focus on what truly matters to the other person.

content: Use this question at the beginning of one-on-ones or check-ins.
Pause and listen fully after asking.
Resist the urge to jump in with solutions immediately.

title: The AWE Question
summary: Prompt deeper thinking and exploration with a simple follow-up question.

details.content: The AWE ('And What Else?') question encourages the other person to dig deeper, often revealing more than their initial response.
After someone shares a challenge, ask, 'And what else?' to encourage them to explore further options or underlying issues.

content: Use 'And what else?' multiple times in a conversation.
Stay curious and patient—let the other person fill the silence.
Avoid leading or suggesting answers.

title: The Focus Question
summary: Help others identify the core challenge by narrowing the conversation.

details.content: People often present surface-level problems; this question helps clarify the real issue that needs attention.
Ask, 'What's the real challenge here for you?' to guide someone toward the heart of their concern.

content: Repeat the question if the conversation drifts.
Listen for emotional cues that signal the real challenge.
Encourage specificity in responses.

title: The Foundation Question
summary: Uncover what the other person needs to feel supported and successful.

details.content: Understanding needs builds trust and ensures the conversation is genuinely helpful.
Ask, 'What do you want?' to clarify expectations and avoid misunderstandings.

content: Ask this question when you sense ambiguity or frustration.
Be prepared for answers that may surprise you.
Use follow-up questions to clarify needs.

title: The Lazy Question
summary: Empower others by asking them to take the lead in seeking support.

details.content: This question shifts responsibility and initiative to the other person, fostering independence and accountability.
Ask, 'How can I help?' to prompt the other person to articulate the support they need.

content: Use this question instead of jumping in with solutions.
Listen carefully to the response and clarify if needed.
Be willing to say no if the request is unreasonable.

title: The Strategic Question
summary: Encourage thoughtful decision-making by exploring possible consequences.

details.content: This question helps people consider the impact of their choices and plan for outcomes.
Ask, 'If you’re saying yes to this, what are you saying no to?' to highlight trade-offs and priorities.

content: Use this question when someone is considering a new commitment.
Encourage reflection on priorities and resources.
Discuss potential risks and benefits openly.

title: The Learning Question
summary: Promote growth by helping others reflect on what they’ve learned.

details.content: Reflection solidifies learning and encourages continuous improvement.
Ask, 'What was most useful for you?' at the end of a conversation to reinforce insights and takeaways.

content: End meetings or coaching sessions with this question.
Allow time for thoughtful responses.
Acknowledge and celebrate learning moments.
